title: 109_hr450
content: The Act may be cited as the "National Science Education Incentive Act of 2005". The Congress finds that the United States must maintain its position in science and technology to advance human understanding and improve lives. More than half of the country's economic growth is directly linked to this. The United States must maintain its preeminent position in science and technology to advance human understanding and improve lives. Over half of the country's economic growth is directly linked to research and development in science and technology, which explores the universe and seeks answers to new questions. The United States must maintain its leading role in science and technology research and development to advance human understanding and improve lives. Fundamental research explores the universe and seeks answers to new questions, while applied research applies these answers to everyday problems faced by individuals, organizations, and governments. This promotes effectiveness in the United States. Research applies basic science answers to everyday problems faced by individuals, organizations, and governments to make lives more meaningful and livable. The United States' economic growth depends on its intellectual capital and innovativeness, with education being critical for developing this resource. Education programs should cater to different kinds of intellectual capital, including scientists and engineers. The United States' economic growth relies on intellectual capital and innovativeness, with education playing a critical role in developing this resource. Education programs need to cater to scientists, engineers, technologically proficient workers, and scientifically literate voters and consumers. The United States' economic growth relies on research and development, technologically proficient workers, and scientifically literate voters and consumers. Student performance in math and science shows shortcomings in K-12 education compared to other countries. Student performance in math and science on international assessments highlights the need for improved K-12 education in the United States. New teaching methods, better curricula, teacher training, and parental involvement are necessary to build on past accomplishments. To build on past accomplishments in math and science education, new teaching methods, improved curricula, teacher training, and parental involvement are essential. Science education emphasizes inquiry and learning through hands-on experiences. Science is a process of inquiry based on observations and data, leading to an understanding of the universe through concepts and theories. Students should learn science by doing experiments and focusing on concepts. Early and continuous science education is important to nurture children's natural curiosity. Science education should be object-oriented, experiment-centered, and concept-based, starting at an early age and continuing throughout school. Teachers play a crucial role in connecting students with the content they are learning. High-quality teachers should be recruited by offering a respected, financially rewarding, and intellectually stimulating career. Teachers are essential in connecting students with the content they learn. Recruiting high-quality teachers who are knowledgeable in their subject area and curriculum is crucial. Incentives and training are necessary for teachers to remain in the classroom and improve their practice. Teachers must have incentives to remain in the classroom and improve their practice, and training is essential for superior results. They need to be knowledgeable in their content area, curriculum, up-to-date research in teaching and learning, and techniques to connect with their students. A new section, SEC. 36, provides a refundable credit for undergraduate tuition paid by certain teachers. This aims to support teachers in improving their practice and staying in the classroom. The new section, SEC. 36, offers a refundable credit for undergraduate tuition paid by eligible teachers, equal to 10 percent of qualified tuition, with a maximum credit of $1,000 per year. Teachers in high-needs school districts may receive this credit for the first 5 years of teaching in elementary or secondary schools. The new section, SEC. 36, provides a refundable credit for undergraduate tuition paid by eligible teachers, with a maximum credit of $1,000 per year. Teachers in high-needs school districts teaching in elementary or secondary schools may receive a higher credit of $1,500 for the first 5 years. No credit is allowed after the 10th year. The Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 provides a refundable credit for undergraduate tuition paid by eligible teachers, with a maximum credit of $1,000 per year. Teachers in high-needs school districts may receive a higher credit of $1,500 for the first 5 years. No credit is allowed after the 10th year. The tax credit for eligible teachers is allowed for up to 10 years, with a definition of an eligible teacher being someone who teaches full-time in grades K-12 and primarily in math, science, engineering, or technology courses. The tax credit is available for eligible teachers who teach full-time in grades K-12, focusing on math, science, engineering, or technology courses. Teachers eligible for the tax credit must teach math, science, engineering, or technology courses in grades K-12, have a relevant degree, and be highly qualified. Teachers eligible for the tax credit must have a degree in math, science, engineering, or technology, teach in grades K-12, and be highly qualified. School administrative functions can also qualify as teaching courses. For tax credit eligibility, teachers must have a degree in specific subjects, teach in K-12, and be highly qualified. School administrative functions can count as teaching courses if they relate to such courses or focus on them. Qualified undergraduate tuition refers to higher education expenses. For tax credit eligibility, teachers must have a degree in specific subjects and be highly qualified. School administrative functions can count as teaching courses if they relate to such courses or focus on them. Qualified undergraduate tuition refers to higher education expenses for enrollment at an institution of higher education. The text discusses tax credit eligibility for teachers with specific degrees and qualifications. It mentions that school administrative functions can count as teaching courses if they are related. Qualified undergraduate tuition refers to higher education expenses for enrollment at an institution of higher education as defined by the Higher Education Act of 1965. Regulations will be prescribed by the Secretary to carry out the purposes of this section. The text discusses tax credit eligibility for teachers with specific degrees and qualifications, including school administrative functions counting as teaching courses if related. Qualified undergraduate tuition refers to higher education expenses at an institution defined by the Higher Education Act of 1965. The Secretary will prescribe regulations to carry out the purposes of this section. Amendments are made to section 1324(b) of title 31, United States Code, and the table of sections for subpart C of part IV of subchapter A of chapter 1 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The text discusses tax credits for teachers with specific qualifications and contributions benefiting STEM education at the elementary and secondary school level. Amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after the enactment date, with only eligible teacher periods after that date considered for tax purposes. SEC. 4 introduces tax credits for contributions benefiting STEM education at the elementary and secondary school level under SEC. 45J of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The tax credit for elementary and secondary STEM contributions is equal to 100% of qualified expenses, including STEM school contributions, teacher externship expenses, and teacher training expenses. The term `qualified STEM contributions' includes STEM school contributions, STEM teacher externship expenses, and STEM teacher training expenses. STEM school contributions consist of STEM property and service contributions. STEM property contributions refer to the deductible amount for charitable contributions of STEM inventory property. STEM property contributions are the deductible amount for charitable contributions of STEM inventory property to elementary or secondary schools in the US or defense dependents' education system. The deductible amount for charitable contributions of STEM inventory property to elementary or secondary schools in the US or defense dependents' education system is subject to specific criteria such as the use of the property by the donee being within the United States or defense dependents' education system, the property fitting into the donee's education plan, and the original use of the property beginning with the donee. The criteria for charitable contributions of STEM inventory property to K-12 schools include the property being related to the donee's purpose, the original use beginning with the donee, fitting into the education plan, not being exchanged for money or other property, and being used in accordance with specific provisions. The criteria for charitable contributions of STEM inventory property to K-12 schools include the property being related to the donee's purpose, fitting into the education plan, and being used in accordance with specific provisions. The determination of the deduction amount under section 170 for STEM inventory property is subject to certain limitations. STEM service contributions refer to the amount paid or incurred for STEM-related services. The deduction amount for STEM inventory property under section 170 is determined as if the limitation under section 170(e)(3)(B) applied to all STEM inventory property. STEM service contributions refer to the amount paid for STEM services provided for the exclusive benefit of students at specific schools. The term 'STEM inventory property' refers to any property contributed to a school for STEM services provided exclusively for students at specific schools, with no charge imposed for the services. The term 'STEM inventory property' includes property donated to schools for STEM education in grades K-12, focusing on science, technology, engineering, and mathematics. The term 'STEM inventory property' refers to property donated to schools for STEM education in grades K-12, specifically in the areas of science, technology, engineering, and mathematics. STEM services are services needed by schools to provide education in these subjects, including teaching courses. The term 'STEM services' refers to services needed by schools to provide education in science, technology, engineering, or mathematics in grades K-12. The term 'defense dependents' education system' refers to the program established under the Defense Dependents' Education Act of 1978. The term 'STEM teacher externship expenses' refers to amounts paid for STEM externship programs under the Defense Dependents' Education Act of 1978. The term 'STEM teacher externship expenses' refers to amounts paid for STEM externship programs for eligible STEM teachers, including stipends. The term 'STEM externship program' refers to training programs for eligible STEM teachers in science, technology, engineering, or mathematics to enhance their teaching skills or knowledge in these areas. The STEM externship program provides training for eligible STEM teachers in grades K-12 to enhance their teaching skills in science, technology, engineering, or mathematics. Eligible STEM teachers must work at educational organizations in the United States. Eligible STEM teachers in grades K-12 at educational organizations in the United States must teach science, technology, engineering, or mathematics courses. The term 'STEM teacher training expenses' refers to costs incurred by a taxpayer in the fields of science, technology, engineering, or mathematics for training eligible STEM teachers. These teachers must teach STEM courses at educational organizations in the United States. The term 'STEM teacher training expenses' refers to costs incurred by a taxpayer in the fields of science, technology, engineering, or mathematics for training eligible teachers. This training must enhance the teacher's skills in STEM areas as determined by their school. No double benefit is allowed for deductions or credits under this section. Conforming amendments are also made. Employees of the taxpayer must enhance their teaching skills in science, technology, engineering, or mathematics as determined by their school. No double benefit is allowed for deductions or credits under this section. Conforming amendments are made to the Code. The taxpayer's employees must improve their STEM teaching skills as determined by their school. Conforming amendments are made to the Code to include a new STEM contributions credit. The amendments in Sec. 45J focus on contributions benefiting STEM education at the elementary and secondary school level. The effective date for these changes is after the enactment of the Act. Additionally, Sec. 5 ensures continued local control over educational institutions and school systems, prohibiting any federal direction or supervision over curriculum, instruction, or personnel.
